ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Physiologic modulation of ear canal noise floor
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Unique, asymptomatic physiologic phenomenon characterized by transient broadband spikes in the noise floor, audible to an otologist but not the patient.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Patulous Eustachian Tube Dysfunction
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Ruled out; spikes did not coincide with nasal breathing or forced breathing manipulations.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Saccade-Induced Tympanic Membrane Movements
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Ruled out; eye gaze shifts and closed eyes did not alter spike frequency or amplitude.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Middle Ear Myoclonus
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Ruled out; frequency of spikes was lower than typical tremors, and no tympanic membrane movements were observed.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Paraganglioma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Ruled out; normal otoscopy and spikes were not coincident with the patient's pulse.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Physical exam of the ear and objective listening with Toynbee tube.
Evaluation of cochlear function and analysis of noise floor anomalies.
Experimental manipulations to identify the source of noise floor spikes.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The participant has normal hearing sensitivity and normal DPOAE amplitudes. However, a unique, asymptomatic physiologic phenomenon was observed consisting of transient broadband noise floor 'spikes' (42-50 dB SPL). These were audible to the otologist via stethoscope but not the patient. Extensive troubleshooting ruled out common causes like patulous eustachian tube or myoclonus; the source appears modulated by neck pressure and heart rate (exercise) but remains poorly understood.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally. PTA Right 8.3 dB HL, Left 10 dB HL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT 10 dB HL bilaterally, consistent with pure-tone averages.

tests.name: Otologic Examination
tests.result_summary: Normal tympanic membranes. Faint 'click' heard by otologist via Toynbee tube (Right > Left); inaudible to patient.

tests.name: DPOAE and Noise Floor Analysis
tests.result_summary: Normal DPOAE amplitudes. Transient broadband spikes in noise floor (mean 42.35 +/- 5.58 dB SPL, max ~50 dB SPL) with interspike interval 35-75 seconds.

tests.name: Physiologic Modulation Troubleshooting
tests.result_summary: Ruled out PETD, eye movements, posture changes, and jaw muscle contraction. Neck pressure altered spike amplitude; exercise increased spike frequency.

proposed_items: Monitor for development of audiologic symptoms
No active medical or surgical treatment required
counseling_actions: Inform patient that hearing sensitivity is normal
Explain that the faint sound detected is audible to the otologist but not to her, and is considered harmless
Discuss that common causes like muscle spasms or breathing issues have been ruled out
Advise that the finding is a unique physiologic signal that does not currently require treatment

escalation.rationale_short: The participant is asymptomatic and the finding appears benign, though unexplained.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor for any future development of audiologic symptoms related to the anomaly.

expected_outcome: Consistency of the spiking phenomenon was observed over days, weeks, and months of testing.
The participant remained asymptomatic regarding the anomaly.
Hypothesis generated that middle ear filtering influences the measures of the spikes, acting as a bandpass filter.
